M: charge (a person or a property) with a payment, such as a tax or a fine

Our house hasn't been assessed in years
capable of being assessed especially for the purpose of taxation
a person (or property) that is assessed

the market value set on assets
anything of material value or usefulness that is owned by a person or company
insulting terms of address for people who are stupid or irritating or ridiculous

In the syllable /si/, the /s/ sibilates in Japanese
the development of a consonant phoneme into a sibilant

marked by care and persistent effort

The teacher assigned him to lead his classmates in the exercise

The biologist assigned the mushroom to the proper class
legally transferable to the ownership of another
appointed to a post or duty
(law) the party to whom something is assigned (e.g., someone to whom a right or property is legally transferred)
a duty that you are assigned to perform (especially in the armed forces)
the instrument by which a claim or right or interest or property is transferred from one person to another
the act of distributing something to designated places or persons
the first task is the assignment of an address to each datum
an undertaking that you have been assigned to do (as by an instructor)

able to be absorbed and incorporated into body tissues
Immigrants often want to assimilate quickly
This country assimilates immigrants very quickly
take (gas, light or heat) into a solution
The nasal assimilates to the following consonant
capable of taking (gas, light, or liquids) into a solution
the state of being assimilated; people of different backgrounds come to see themselves as part of a larger national family
the social process of absorbing one cultural group into harmony with another
the process of absorbing nutrients into the body after digestion
a linguistic process by which a sound becomes similar to an adjacent sound
in the theories of Jean Piaget: the application of a general schema to a particular instance

act as an assistant in a subordinate or supportive function
a person who contributes to the fulfillment of a need or furtherance of an effort or purpose

having help; often used as a combining form
the regulation of weights and measures of articles offered for sale
an ancient writ issued by a court of assize to the sheriff for the recovery of property
the county courts of England (replaced in 1971 by Crown courts)

M: the capability of being easily associated or joined or connected in thought
having partial rights and privileges or subordinate status
a person with subordinate membership in a society, institution, or commercial enterprise
associates in the law firm bill at a lower rate than do partners
any event that usually accompanies or is closely connected with another
first was the lightning and then its thunderous associate
the position of associate (as in an office or academy)
a formal organization of people or groups of people
he joined the Modern Language Association
the act of consorting with or joining with others
you cannot be convicted of criminal guilt by association
the state of being connected together as in memory or imagination
his association of his father with being beaten was too strong to break
the process of bringing ideas or events together in memory or imagination
conditioning is a form of learning by association
a relation resulting from interaction or dependence
flints were found in association with the prehistoric remains of the bear
the host is not always injured by association with a parasite
(chemistry) any process of combination (especially in solution) that depends on relatively weak chemical bonding
(ecology) a group of organisms (plants and animals) that live together in a certain geographical region and constitute a community with a few dominant species
of or relating to associations or associationism
(psychology) a theory that association is the basic principle of mental activity
characterized by or causing or resulting from the process of bringing ideas or events together in memory or imagination
the repetition of similar vowels in the stressed syllables of successive words
having the same sound (especially the same vowel sound) occurring in successive stressed syllables
note the assonant words and syllables in `tilting at windmills'
having the same vowel sound occurring with different consonants in successive words or stressed syllables
correspond in vowel sounds; rhyme in assonance
The accented vowels assonated in this poem

sundry sciences commonly known as social"- I.A.Richards
of many different kinds purposefully arranged but lacking any uniformity
his disguises are many and various
various experiments have failed to disprove the theory
